metadata.case_name: Golak Nath & Ors. v. State of Punjab & Anr.

facts.text: Henry Golak Nath died on July 30, 1953. Petitioners are his son, daughter and granddaughters.

Financial Commissioner, Punjab, in revision against order of Additional Commissioner, Jullundur Division, held by order dated January 22, 1962 that 418 standard acres and 9-1/4 units was surplus in hands of petitioners under Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act, 1953 read with s. 10-B.
Petitioners filed writ petition No. 153 of 1966 under Art. 32 alleging provisions declaring surplus void as infringing Arts. 14, 19(1)(f) and (g).

Writ Petitions Nos. 202 and 205 of 1966 filed challenging Mysore Land Reforms Act, 10 of 1962 as amended by Act 14 of 1965, fixing ceilings on land holdings and conferring ownership of surplus lands on tenants, as infringing Arts. 14, 19 and 31.

Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, 1964 amended Art. 31A, extended definition of 'estate' to include ryotwari and agricultural lands, and added Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act, 1953 (item 54) and Mysore Land Reforms Act, 1962 (item 51) to Ninth Schedule.
Earlier decisions: Sankari Prasad (1951) upheld First Amendment; Sajjan Singh (1965) upheld 17th Amendment indirectly.
7 parties intervened in WP 153/1966; notice to Advocates General of various States.

legal_issues.text: Whether Parliament under Art. 368 has power to amend Part III of Constitution so as to take away or abridge fundamental rights.
Whether 'law' in Art. 13(2) includes constitutional amendment, making such amendments void if abridging fundamental rights.
Source of amending power: Art. 368 or Arts. 245, 246, 248 with List I Entry 97.
Whether 17th Amendment requires ratification under proviso to Art. 368 as affecting Art. 226 or state legislative powers.
Applicability of doctrine of prospective overruling.
Validity of Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act, 1953 and Mysore Land Reforms Act, 1962 post-17th Amendment.

petitioner_arguments.text: Constitution intended to be permanent; amendment cannot injure, maim or destroy its indestructible character or basic structure including fundamental rights.
Word 'amendment' implies change within original framework for improvement, not destruction of fundamental rights.
Fundamental rights part of basic structure; power to amend preserves, not destroys them.
Limits on amending power implied in Art. 368; wide words like 'repeal and re-enact' used elsewhere indicate limitation.
Constituent Assembly debates, speeches of Nehru and Ambedkar show no intention to allow repeal of fundamental rights.
Art. 13(2) 'law' includes constitutional amendments; such abridging FRs void.
17th Amendment detracts from Art. 226 jurisdiction and state legislative powers, requires proviso to Art. 368.

respondent_arguments.text: Constitutional amendment exercises sovereign power, partakes character of Constitution itself, not ordinary legislative power.
Art. 368 clear, no implied limitations; rigid vs flexible Constitution distinction based on express limits.
Amending power safety valve against revolution; no basic/non-basic features, all amendable.
Constituent Assembly debates not conclusive; nothing excludes FRs from amendment.
Art. 13(2) does not control Art. 368; amendment not 'law' under Art. 13(2).
Amendments enforce Directive Principles; reversal causes chaos.
Arts. 31A, 31B, Ninth Schedule do not affect Art. 226 or state powers requiring ratification.

court_reasoning.text: Fundamental rights primordial, transcendental, beyond Parliament's reach except as per Constitution scheme; Parts III & IV integrated but FRs immutable subject to social control.
court_reasoning.key_observation: FRs given permanence; Parliament cannot abridge via amendment.

court_reasoning.text: Amending power from Arts. 245,246,248 & List I Entry 97, not Art. 368 (procedure only); constitutional amendment is 'law' under Art. 13(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art. 13(2) applies to amendments abridging FRs.

court_reasoning.text: Sankari Prasad & Sajjan Singh overruled as erroneous; longer held, greater erosion of FRs.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Duty to correct constitutional errors promptly.

court_reasoning.text: 17th Amendment void for abridging FRs but prospective overruling applied: no retroactivity to avoid chaos.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Doctrine confines to future; preserves past transactions.

court_reasoning.text: Impugned Acts valid under Arts. 31A, 31B as amended previously.
Dissent (Wanchoo etc.): Art. 368 confers full power including FRs; amendment not 'law' under 13(2); reaffirm Sankari Prasad.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No implied limitations; stare decisis applies.

court_reasoning.text: Hidayatullah J: Amending power sui generis; FRs not abridgeable; s.3 of 17th Amendment invalid but Acts valid under 31A.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ninth Schedule misuse but new 'estate' definition protected.

holdings.text: Parliament has no power under Art. 368 to amend Part III to abridge/take away FRs; such amendments void under Art. 13(2).
Amending power derives from Arts. 245-248, not Art. 368 alone.
Doctrine of prospective overruling applied: decision prospective; past amendments (1st,4th,17th) valid.
Punjab & Mysore Acts valid; petitions dismissed.

precedents_cited.relevance: Held Parliament could amend FRs; overruled as wrong.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Central to whether amendments abridging FRs valid; 17th Amendment amends 31A, adds to Ninth Schedule.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act, 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Declares surplus land; protected by 17th Amendment.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Land Reforms Act, 1962 (as amended by Act 14 of 1965)
statutes_cited.relevance: Fixes ceilings, confers tenant rights; protected.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, 1964
statutes_cited.relevance: Amends estate definition, adds Acts to Ninth Schedule; void for abridging FRs but prospective.

outcome.summary: By 6:5 majority, held FRs not amendable to abridge/take away; amendments 'law' under Art.13(2); source legislative power; prospective overruling: past amendments valid, future cannot abridge FRs. Impugned Acts valid under 31A/31B. Writs dismissed.

key_quotes.text: Fundamental rights are the primordial rights necessary for the development of human personality.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines nature of FRs as transcendental.

key_quotes.text: The incapacity of Parliament therefore in exercise of its amending power to modify, restrict, or impose fundamental freedoms in Part III arises from the scheme of the Constitution.
The doctrine of prospective overruling can be invoked only in matters arising under our Constitution... the scope of the retrospective operation... is left to its discretion.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Adopts prospective overruling for first time in India.

key_quotes.text: Article 368 carries the power to amend all parts of the Constitution including the fundamental rights in Part III.
key_quotes.speaker: court
